meanings.def: a long thin straight piece of wood or metal, especially one with the end placed in the ground, used as a support
examples: A punt is a boat that you move by pushing a long pole against the bottom of the river.
I stood resting on my ski poles and watched her come down the slope.
The tent poles are made of aluminium

meanings.def: either of the two points at the opposite ends of the line on which the earth or any other planet turns
examples: The meridian is an imaginary line drawn from pole to pole.
The north magnetic pole lies to the west of the geographic North Pole.

meanings.def: either of the two ends of a magnet, or the positive or negative points of an electric battery
either of two opposite or very different extremes
examples: Their opinions were at opposite poles of the debate.
an artistic compromise between the poles of abstraction and representation

meanings.def: to be widely separated; to have no interests that you share
examples: Her own friends were poles apart from his.
In temperament, she and her sister are poles apart.

meanings.def: used to refer to the difficult way to the top of a profession
to refuse to get involved with somebody/something or in a particular situation
examples: Personally, I wouldn’t touch him or his business with a ten-foot pole.

idioms.def: to be widely separated; to have no interests that you share

idioms.def: used to refer to the difficult way to the top of a profession

idioms.idiom: not touch somebody/something with a ten-foot pole
idioms.def: to refuse to get involved with somebody/something or in a particular situation

meanings.def: to move a boat by pushing on the bottom of a river, etc. with a pole
examples: He hired a punt and poled upstream.
